test_case_name: Change permissions to make file executable
env_setup:
#Initial clean-up
Execute rm -r ~/Desktop/oi/* to start with fresh test directory.
# Create scripts directory and file
mkdir -p ~/Desktop/oi/scripts
cat > ~/Desktop/oi/scripts/backup.sh << 'EOF'
#!/bin/bash
echo "Backing up user files..."
mkdir -p ~/Desktop/oi/backup
cp -r ~/Desktop/oi/data/* ~/Desktop/oi/backup/
echo "Backup completed successfully."
EOF
# Set initial permissions (read/write but not executable)
chmod 644 ~/Desktop/oi/scripts/backup.sh
# Create data directory with sample file
mkdir -p ~/Desktop/oi/data
echo "Sample data" > ~/Desktop/oi/data/sample.txt
prompt: I need to run my backup script. Could you please make the backup.sh file in the scripts folder executable?
expected_behaviour: The agent should locate the backup.sh file in the ~/Desktop/oi/scripts folder and modify its permissions to make it executable using the chmod command (e.g., `chmod +x ~/Desktop/oi/scripts/backup.sh`). The agent should confirm the permission change was successful, potentially by displaying the new permissions (755 or -rwxr-xr-x). Achieving a similar outcome using any reasonable method is perfectly acceptable.
